revision.text:
Hi I'm User:InConversationwithAlan
[[User:InConversationwithAlan|InConversationwithAlan]] ([[User talk:InConversationwithAlan|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/InConversationwithAlan|contribs]]) 01:54, 28 April 2014 (UTC)

If you are used to the syntax of MediaWiki templates, then you might be wondering about the syntax of the #invoke statement we saw in the previous chapter. The #invoke statement looked like this: 
{{#invoke:Hello|hello_world}}
As you can see, there are three parts: #invoke:, Hello, and hello_world. If we compare this to a template that does the same thing - outputs the text "Hello, world!" - we can see that there is only one part. 
{{Hello}}
The shared part is Hello, and in both cases this corresponds to the page name. For #invoke, it corresponds to the page [[Module:Hello]], and for the template it corresponds to the page [[Template:Hello]]. This leaves us with two extra parts to the #invoke statement: the #invoke: code itself, and hello_world. The #invoke: code is quite straightforward; all it is there to do is to tell the MediaWiki software that it is dealing with a Lua module, and not with a template or any other kind of special text.Text that has a special function in MediaWiki is known as a ''magic word'', and technically an #invoke statement is a particular kind of magic word called a ''parser function''. You can see more documentation about magic words and parser functions at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Magic_words. The hello_world code is where things get interesting. You may have noticed that hello_world appears in the middle of [[Module:Hello]]: p = {} function p.hello_world() return "Hello, world!" end return p It appears in a block of that starts with the keyword "function" and ends with the keyword "end". This is a ''function''. Functions in Lua are a lot like MediaWiki templates. You give templates input, the template processes the input, and it gives you some output. Functions are just the same; you give them input, the function processes the input, and it returns some output. In this case, we are not providing any input, as our function is very simple. (Later we will learn how to use the parentheses after hello_world to control input we are given.) The output in Lua functions is provided by the return keyword. In this case we are saying, "make a function with no inputs that outputs the text 'Hello, world!'" At the same time, we have given the function a name. while there are other ways to define a function in Lua, in this example the function name is everything after the code function and before the parentheses. In other words, the function name is p.hello_world. So why the p.? Why not just make the name hello_world? The answer is that the p. is how we tell Scribunto that we want our function to be available from #invoke. If we leave out the p., then we cannot run our function directly from any wiki pages. (There are ways that the function can be run ''indirectly'', but we will not cover those for now.) == Notes == {{BookCat}}

'''Amy Stroupe and BB&T''' is a professional ethics case that concerns whistleblowing. Amy Stroupe was hired by [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] on August 1, 2005 as a [[w:certified fraud examiner|certified fraud examiner]] (CFE) in Charlotte, N.C., and her courage as a [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblower]] and dedication to encourage transparency within [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] are tribute to her professionalism. In February, 2007, concerns were raised about a series of suspicious loans made by a [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] financial center manager in a real estate development, and Stroupe was notified by a retail service officer. In her investigative report, she indicated that a [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] employee had helped Village of Penland's developer design a $100 million [[w:Ponzi scheme|Ponzi scheme]]. <ref name=HuffingtonPost>Baker, M. (2010). Amy Stroupe: BB&T whistleblower vindicated by court ruling, to be rehired. Huffington Post. Retrieved from http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/02/amy-stroupe-bbt-whistlebl_n_523563.html</ref> [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] fired Stroupe soon after a meeting with the [[w:FBI|FBI]], claiming that she had violated company policies during her investigation, though she countered in court that she was fired as punishment for pushing too hard on the investigation.<ref name=InvestigativeFund>Hudson, M. (2010). When whistle-blowers fight back. The Investigative Fund. Retrieved from http://www.theinvestigativefund.org/investigations/economiccrisis/1314/when_whistle-blowers_fight_back </ref> She sued [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] under [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblower]] provisions, Section 806, and the federal judge in the case ruled that [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] must reinstate Stroupe with back pay. <ref name="FraudMag" />
==Professional Career==
===Early Career=== Prior to her career at BB&T, she worked for the Cleveland County, N.C., Sheriff's Office as a detective. <ref name=FraudMag>Carozza, D. (2010). Sentinel wins vindication: An interview with Amy Stroupe, CFE, 2010 ACFE sentinel award recipient. Fraud Magazine. Retrieved from http://www.fraud-magazine.com/article.aspx?id=4294968657</ref>
===Whistleblowing and BB&T=== Stroupe began working for BB&T at their Shelby branch on August 1, 2005, and while employed she excelled at her job as a corporate investigator. In her 90 day review report, her supervisor wrote, “Amy is an asset to the BB&T Corporate Investigations team. Amy has established herself as a consistent contributor to the investigative team.”<ref name=Amyvs> Stroupe v. BB&T. No. 07CUS2801. Cleveland County Superior Court. 6 December 2007. Retrieved from http://www.scribd.com/doc/3344601/Amy-Stroupe-v-BBT</ref> During her two years with BB&T, she had five positive performance reviews.<ref name="FraudMag" />
In February 2007, Stroupe was alerted about suspicious loans with Peerless Development Group. A branch manager named Bryan Drum had approved $20 million in loans for a development called the Villages of Penland.<ref name="Amyvs" /> Several suspicious patterns were apparent: all loan applicants were from out of state, the lots were appraised at a higher value than they were worth, all loans had the same appraiser and closing attorney, and Peerless used funds from their account to pay for some customer’s loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> Additionally, Drum was the only employee who worked with the Peerless loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> She first notified her supervisor, Brian Prater, and the Direct Retail division of her findings, but when no action was taken, she notified the Regional Portfolio administrator. Later, Stroupe informed the FBI; Charlie Mattox, Drum’s supervisor; and several other BB&T employees including the Regional President. In one meeting, an employee noted that the case “looks like securities fraud."<ref name="Amyvs" /> Upon further investigation, Stroupe found that Drum had been given a $10,000 bonus for the amount of loans he approved, and Drum had developed an incentive program between Peerless and its customers in which Peerless could pay its customer’s loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> She also visited the Villages of Penland and found little development had been done on any of the lots. Despite her findings, Mattox did not immediately terminate Drum; instead he approved three additional Peerless loans that were already in the process of being approved. He contacted Stroupe advising her to work on other investigations and claimed that many parts of her report about Drum were false.<ref name="Amyvs" /> In April 2007, Drum was fired, and in retaliation, Mattox moved Stroupe from the Shelby branch to the Charlotte headquarters.<ref name="Amyvs" />
On May 22, 2007, a BB&T attorney prevented Stroupe’s report to the FBI from being sent since it contained incriminating information.<ref name="Amyvs" /> BB&T would not only be liable for the $20 million they loaned but also for $120 million loaned to Peerless through other banks. The following day, the attorney stopped Stroupe from attending a meeting with FBI officials stating that she would answer any question they asked her.<ref name="InvestigativeFund" /> Afterwards it was apparent that BB&T denied any involvement in the scandal and failed to mention Bryan Drum. Despite resistance from upper management, Stroupe continued to investigate the scandal, and in retaliation, BB&T fired her on June 20, 2007 stating that she had wrongfully discussed the details of her investigation with unauthorized personnel.<ref name="FraudMag" /> At this time, her boss said, “Amy, it’s become obvious that you cannot conform to a corporate setting; therefore, we are terminating your employment." <ref name="FraudMag" />
===Aftermath=== After termination, Stroupe filed a complaint with OSHA, but after months of investigation, they found that her claims lacked any merit.<ref name=Ruling>Galindo, D. (2012). Ruling in BB&T case likely to take months Fraud Magazine. Retrieved from http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/ruling-in-bb-t-case-likely-to-take-months/article_80092f03-8fc1-56cb-b8e9-5dd42e52fbe6.html?mode=jqm</ref> She appealed under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act afterwards and won three years later winning her job back and back pay plus interest.<ref name="InvestigativeFund"/> Her case is notable because it is one of the 3.6% that have won under the SOX act.<ref name="InvestigativeFund"/>
==Whistleblowing== [[w:Whistleblower|Whistleblowing]] refers to making a disclosure that evidences illegal or improper government or corporate activities. <ref name=Fas>Whitaker, L. P. (2007). The whistleblower protection act: An overview. CRS Report for Congress. Retrieved from http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RL33918.pdf</ref> By disclosing information about corruption, fraud, mismanagement and other wrongdoing, [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] have helped save billions of dollars in public funds while preventing emerging scandals and disasters from worsening. <ref name=TransInt>Transparency International. (2013). International principles for whistleblower legislation: Best practices for laws to protect whistleblowers and support whistleblowing in the public interest. Retrieved from http://www.transparency.org/whatwedo/pub/international_principles_for_whistleblower_legislation </ref> ===Perception and Protection=== Perceptions of [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] tend to vary. While sources such as [[w:Time (magazine)|Time]] have often praised whistleblowers for their actions, others have accused them of being traitors. <ref name=Time>Person of the year: A photo history. (2002). Retrieved from http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2019712_2019710_2019677,00.html </ref><ref name=Traitor>Harwood, W. H. (2013). Whistleblower or traitor, Snowden must shut up. Huffington Post. Retrieved from http://www.huffingtonpost.com/william-h-harwood/whistleblower-or-traitor-_b_4143834.html </ref> Since [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers']] broad spectrum of public perception deepens the riskiness of their actions, civil society has played a large role in protecting whistleblowers from public retaliation, legal liability, and cultural barriers. <ref name=SSRN>Banisar, D. (2011). Whistleblowing: International standards and developments. Social Science Research Network. Retrieved from http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1753180 </ref> In recent decades, many non-governmental organizations such as [[w:Transparency International|Transparency International]], [[w:Government Accountability Project| Government Accountability Project]], Public Concern at Work, and the Open Democracy Advice Centre have arisen to inspire legislative protection for whistleblowers apropos their risks and publicize corruption across international workplaces. Efforts to improve and expand whistleblowing legislation have helped protect [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] from their risks, while also easing detection of corruption and enhancing accountability in corporate and political environments. <ref name=TransInt /> Though the threshold for whistleblower protection is difficult to define, current principles regarding whistleblowing legislation suggest protection should be granted for disclosures made with a reasonable belief of wrongdoing at the time of disclosure. <ref name=TransInt /> Though these principles don’t always translate into legislation, they help direct the formulation of new and improvement of current legislation.
===United States Legislation=== Whistleblowing's history is deep. In 1863, the [[w:False Claims Act|United States False Claims Act]] allowed citizens to sue on the government's behalf in cases of fraud and collect rewards for doing so. <ref name=SSRN /> This action is often known as [[w:Qui tam|qui tam]], a writ originating in Roman times as a law enforcement mechanism. <ref name=GeorgiaLaw> Beck, J. R. (2000). The False Claims Act and the English eradication of qui tam legislation. University of Georgia School of Law. Retrieved from http://digitalcommons.law.uga.edu/fac_artchop/279/ </ref> Whistleblowing was modernly campaigned by [[w:Ralph Nader|Ralph Nader]] in the 1960s when he launched a movement to encourage scientists, engineers, and other professionals to "blow the whistle" on unethical principles by their employers. <ref name=Science>Boffey, P. (1971). Nader and the scientists: A call for responsibility. Science, 171(3917), 549-551. Retrieved from http://www.sciencemag.org/content/171/3971/549.extract </ref> Following his drive and tragedies like the [[w:Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Challenger disaster of 1986]], many whistleblowing laws were passed such as the [[w:Whistleblower Protection Act| Whistleblower Protection Act of 1989]], which protects government employees from management retaliation and is considered to be among the most important pieces of whistleblower legislation. <ref name=SSRN /> Scandals have also encouraged more recent legislation. In the 2002, the [[w:Enron scandal|Enron]] and [[w:Worldcon|Worldcon]] scandals inspired the adoption of the [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], which requires international corporations that are either owned in part by United States companies or traded on United States stock exchanges to adopt whistleblowing procedures. <ref name=SSRN />
==BB&T==
===Organizational Culture===
===Repercussions===
==Conclusions== ===Professionalism=== ===Whistleblower Protection=== There are 18 different acts which protect whistleblowers within the Unites States. <ref name=WhistleblowerActs>Whistleblowerlaws. (2014). Whistleblower Protections. Whistleblowerlaws. Retrieved from http://www.whistleblowerlaws.com/whistleblower-protections-act/</ref> The [[w:Sarbanes Oxley Act (SOX)|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] is the primary protection act which defends individuals who report financial fraud with “strong and unprecendented anti-retatliation protection for corporate employees.” This act has been unsuccessful in protecting whistleblowers, however, yielding a win rate of 3.6% in initial trials and 6.5% in appeals. <ref name=WilliamAndMaryLawReview>Moberly, R. (2007). Unfulfilled Expectations: An Empirical Analysis of Why Sarbanes-Oxley Whisleblowers Rarely Win. William and Mary Law Review 49(1). Retrieved from http://scholarship.law.wm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1115&context=wmlr</ref> The case of Amy Stroupe and BB&T shows that federal reporting of misconduct can be successful under the Sarbanes Oxley Act, but this result is rare. Other whistleblowing cases such as Nicholas P. Tides & Matthew C. Neumann v. The Boeing Company resulted in failure using SOX. The motion failed because the court ruled that “leaks to the media are not protected” under SOX. <ref name=BoeingCase>Cougheneur, J. (2010). Nicholas P. Tides & Matthew C. Neumann v. The Boeing Company. United States Court Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Retrieved from http://www.rcfp.org/newsitems/docs/20110504_150355_op.pdf</ref> The purpose for excluding media leaks from protection is to protect confidentiality of corporate financial records. <ref name=MediaExclusionPurpose>Egelko, B. (2011). Boeing ex-employees lose whistle-blower case. SFGate. Retrieved from http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Boeing-ex-employees-lose-whistle-blower-case-2324900.php</ref>
Multiple issues arise, though, from prohibiting reports to the media. First, reporting misconduct internally or to federal authorities is less effective because of pressure from agencies. The U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board found that “agencies have the power to influence employees’ decisions about reporting wrongdoing” and around one-third of people who realized misconduct received pressure to not report. <ref name=MeritReviewBoard>U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board. (2011). Blowing the Whistle: Barriers to Federal Employees Making Disclosures. U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board. Retrieved from http://www.mspb.gov/netsearch/viewdocs.aspx?docnumber=662503&version=664475</ref> Second, reporting of fraud through federal agencies is inherently a much slower and labor intensive process than simply providing information to media outlets. Lastly, a conflict of interest is present for federal agencies that are obligated to protect whistleblowers who harm corporations, even though these agencies receive money from corporations through lobbying. BB&T and Boeing each have given millions of dollars annually to the U.S. government through lobbying. <ref name=OpenSecrets1>Center for Responsive Politics. (2013). Annual Lobbying by Boeing Co. OpenSecrets.org. Retrieved from http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000000100</ref> <ref name=OpenSecrets2>Center for Responsive Politics. (2013). Annual Lobbying by BB&T Corp. OpenSecrets.org. Retrieved from http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000021868</ref> The pressures and problems with financial fraud reporting support the need for inclusion of media leaks in whistleblower protection laws, particularly under the Sarbanes Oxley Act.
==References== <references />
{{BookCat}}

Shouldn't the class that implements the interface use public virtual inheritance to prevent the diamond problem with multiple inheritance of the same interface?

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Galzigler!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:25, 28 April 2014 (UTC)

== You have been warned == {{tmbox|type=notice|text='''Please help ''improve'' Wikibooks'''. Your [[Special:Contributions/68.111.46.150|recent edits]]{{ #if: [[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 20:33, 28 April 2014 (UTC) |, such as those you made to [[History of Wyoming/Native American "Wyoming" to 1868]]}} are considered unconstructive by fellow contributors. Please read [[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks?]] for a description of what we allow. You can ask questions or ask for help in the [[WB:HELP|Assistance Reading Room]]. Please use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] for experimenting with the wiki software in the future.
Thanks. }} You will be blocked from editing if you carry out further vandalism.

page.title: Source SDK: Mastering the Source/What is Hammer?

revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=What is Hammer?|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]}}
What is Hammer? A very simple question, and one that will be covered thoroughly throughout this page. [[File:Application browser-hammer editor.jpg|right|300px]]
=The Hammer World Editor= Hammer, or the Hammer World Editor is a free level editing and creation program supplied by the Source SDK. Hammer comes with a number of unique features other than standard level design programs, making it one of the most popular choices on the market. Hammer has been used to develop many games, both by major video game companies and independent developers, and always shows favorable results. The Hammer Editor is easy to learn with a few tutorials, but with the help of this book, you'll be able to master it and all it has to offer.
=How do I use it?= The Hammer Editor is known for it's easy to learn interface and variety of creation tools. You will literally find an endless array of tools and programs specifically designed to create the level of your choosing, if you can build it in your mind, you can build it in Hammer. Of course you have to learn it first, that's where this book comes in. With your devotion and cooperation with this book you be able to learn every flip, switch, and button in Hammer, and how to master every one.
=Improving your Skills= The goal of this book is to make sure you can understand and operate the Hammer Editor, if all goes correctly, you will notice your skills improve drastically as you move from chapter to chapter in Section 1. These pictures below will give you a clear indication of your soon to be progress through Hammer, and show you what you can expect to accomplish with the help of this book.
All right, now that we've covered just what the Hammer Editor is, it's time to learn how to use it.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=What is Hammer?|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]}}

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Cookbook:Doughnuts]] <!-- Linked from Wikipedia's Doughnut infobox -->

{{cleanup|Grammar needs to be cleaned up}} ==Matter== Matter refers to any physical quantity that can be measured and observed that has Chemical Physical and Electrical properties ===Chemical Properties=== [[Matter]] is made from [[Chemical Element]] : <math>E^m_Z</math>
With : E - Chemical element : m - Mass : Z - Atomic number
Chemical Element exist in three states Solid, Liquid, Gas : [[Solid]] for example Zinc . Zn : [[Liquid]] Mercury , Mg : [[Gas]] Hydrogen . <math>H^1_1</math>
===Physical Properties=== All matter process : [[Mass]] , M , measured in Kg : [[Volume]] , V , measured in m<sup>3</sup> : [[Density]] , D , measured in Kg / m<sup>3</sup> :<math>D = \frac{M}{V}</math>
===Electrical Properties=== Chemical Element is made from [[Atom]] that contains the smallest indivisible [[Charged particles]] called [[Proton]], [[Neutron]] and [[Electron]] that has the following characteristics
Atom is made from a [[Nucleus]] contains Proton and Neutron in the center with circular [[Orbits]] contain Electron circulate around nucleus
:{| class="prettytable" width=100% align=center !Charged particles !! Symbol !! Charge !! Mass |- | [[/Proton/]] || <math>p^-</math> || + || <math>m_p</math> |- | [[/Neutron/]] || <math>n^o-</math> || 0 || <math>m_n</math> |- | [[/Electron/]] || <math>e^-</math> || - || <math>m_e</math> |}
{{bookcat}}

revision.text: @import "//bits.wikimedia.org/en.wikipedia.org/load.php?debug=false&lang=en&modules=user&only=styles&skin=vector&user=Jagot&*";

==Force== Force interacts with matter to perform a task . For example, when pushing or pulling an object to make it move from stationary position . The strength of pushing or pulling is called Force. Force is denoted as F measured in Newton N
==Force Matter Interaction== Force and matter interact follow the 5 Newton's laws below
1 . Matter remains in its state when no Force acts on it
2 . Matter changes its state when Force acts on it
3 . When Force acts on matter, matter will produce an Opposite Force to oppose the Force acts on matter
4 . At equilibrium, the net force act on matter is zero
5 . The attraction force between two objects is directly proportional to thier seperation distance
==Types of Force== ===Gravity Force=== Force the earth attracts matter toward the earth : <math>F_g = G \frac{m M}{R^2}</math>
With : <math>F_G</math> - Gravity Force : <math>G</math> - Attraction constant : <math>m</math> - Matter's mass : <math>M</math> - Earth's mass : <math>R</math> - Seperation distance between matter and Earth
===Motion Force=== Force that sets matter in motion : <math>F_a = m a</math>
With : <math>F_a</math> - Motion Force : <math>m</math> - Mass : <math>a</math> - Acceleration
===Elastic Force=== Restoring Force to return to equilibrium : <math>F_x = -kx</math> : <math>F_y = -ky</math>
With :<math>F_x</math> - Elastic Force in the x direction :<math>F_y</math> - Elastic Force in the y direction :<math>k</math> - Elastic constant :<math>x </math> - Displacement in the x direction :<math>y </math> - Displacement in the y direction
===Friction Force===
===Culomb Force=== The attraction force between two unlike Electric charges : <math>F_Q = K \frac{Q_+ Q_-}{R^2}</math>
With : <math>F_Q </math> - Culomb Force : <math> K </math> - Attraction constance : <math>Q </math> - Electric Charge : <math>R</math> - Seperation distance
===Ampere Force=== Electric Force F_E that sets Electric charge in straight line motion to create Electric Field E : <math>F_E = Q E</math>
With : <math>F_E</math> - Ampere Force : <math>Q </math> - Electric Charge : <math>E</math> - Electric Field
===Lorentz Force=== Magnetic Force F_B that sets moving Electric Charge to move in straight line motion perpendicular to the initial direction travel : <math>F_B = \pm Q v B</math>
With : <math>F_B </math> - Lorentz Force : <math>v </math> - Speed : <math> B</math> - Magnetic Field
===Faraday Force=== The sum of two forces Coulomb force and Ampere force : <math>F_EB = F_E + F_B = QE \pm Qvb = Q (E \pm v B)</math>
With : <math>F_EB </math> - Faraday Force : <math>Q</math> - Electric Charge : <math>v</math> - Speed : <math>E</math> - Electric Field : <math>B</math> - Magnetic Field
==Summary== :{| class="prettytable" width=100% align=center ! Force !! Formula |- | Motion Force || <math>F = m a = \frac{m v}{t} = \frac{p}{t}</math> |- | Gravity Force ||<math>F_g = m g = G \frac{m M}{R^2}</math> |- |Friction Force || |- |Elastic Force ||<math>F = - k x</math> |- |Coulomb Force || <math>F_Q = K \frac{Q_+ Q_-}{R^2}</math> |- |Ampere Force|| <math>F_E = Q E </math> |- ||Lorenz Force || <math>F_B = Q v B</math> |- |Faraday Force || <math>F_EB = F_E + F_B = Q (E \pm vB) </math> |- |}
{{bookcat}}

{{cleanup|As with other pages in this book grammar needs fixing and some parts of unclear. Only English should be used in non-linguistic books on English Wikibooks}} ==Electricity Sources== Electricity comes from many sources # [[/Charged Particles/]] # [[/ElectroStatic/]] # [[/ElectroDynamic/]] # [[/Electrolysis/]] # [[/ElectroVoltaic/]] # [[/PhotoVoltaic/]] # [[/Electromagnetic Induction/]]
===[[Charged Particles]]=== :{| class="prettytable" width=100% ! Charged Particles!! Mass !! Charge !! Symbol |- | Electron || 9.1094 × 10<sup>−31</sup> kg || −1.602 × 10<sup>−19</sup> C || e<sup>-</sup> |- | Proton || 9.1094 × 10<sup>−31</sup> kg || +1.602 × 10<sup>−19</sup> C || p<sup>+</sup> |- |Ntron || 1.6726 ×10<sup>-27</sup> kg || 0 C || 0 |}
===[[ElectroStatic]]=== :{| class="prettytable" width=100% ! Matter !! Charged !! Electric Charge !! S !! Charge !! Electric Field !! Magnetic Field |- | [ ] || + e || [-] || Q || -Q || --> <-- || Vòng tròn thuận chiều kim đồng hồ |- | [ ] || - e || [+] || Q || +Q || <-- --> ||Vòng tròn ngược chiều kim đồng hồ |- |}
==[[Electricity Types]]== There are two kinds of Electricity . DC Electricity and AC Electricity DC Electricity provides constant electricity over time : <math>v(t) = V</math>
AC Electricity provides sinusoidal varying electricity over time : <math>v(t) = V Sin (\omega t + \theta)</math>
==[[Electricity and Matter]]==
Matter that interacts with Electricity are divided into three kinds * [[Conductor]] . Matter that conducts electricity easy * [[Semi-Conductor]] . Matter that does not conduct electricity easy * [[Non-Conductor]] . Matter that does not conduct electricity at all
Conductor and Electricity interact with each other creates * Resistance ,R * Conductance ,Y * Current ,I * Voltage ,V
The relation of the parameters V, I, R, Y can be expressed by the following two laws
* Ohm's Law : <math>\frac{V}{I} = R</math>
* Watt's Law : <math>V \times I = E_V</math>
Matter conducts Electric energy loss as Heat release into the surounding : <math>E_R = I^2 \times R or \frac{V^2}{R}</math>
From above, :<math>V = I \times R</math> :<math>I = \frac{V}{R}</math> :<math>R = \frac{V}{I}</math> :<math>Y = \frac{I}{V}</math>
:<math>E_V = V \times I</math> :<math>E_R = I^2 \times R </math> :<math>E = E_V - V_R </math> :<math>n = \frac{E_V}{E_R}</math>
{{bookcat}}

==Sound Sources== Sound comes from many sources * Human Voice * Animal sound * Collision of objects ==Characteristics== * Sound does not exist in vaccum. * Sound travels in air as Longitudinal wave of thick and thin columns of air with speed that changes with Tempempure and Prereure of the medmum's material : In Air. v = 343 m/s : In liquid. v = : In Solid. v = * Travelling sound hits an obstacle will exhibit the following effects :{| class="prettytable" width=100% align=center ! Wave Effects !! Definition !! Example |- |[[Reflection]] || Wave is reflected back || [[File:Ray Diagram 2.PNG|100px]] |- |[[Refraction]] || Wave does not follow straight line when goes through matter || [[File:Ray_Diagram.PNG]]
|- |[[Diffraction]] || Wave travels thrgh narrow opennings || [[File:Two-Slit_Diffraction.png|200px]] |- |[[Interference]] || Interaction of two waves travel toward each other || [[File:Two-Slit_Diffraction.png|200px]] |- |}
Creates Noise , Echo . No sound , Intermittent
==Applications== ===Sound Machines=== Radio
Cassete
Disc Player
AM/FM Radio Transmitter
AM/FM Radio Tuner
===Sound System=== AM/FM Radio Broadcasting System
{{bookcat}}

{{cleanup|grammar needs to be fixed and there are some unfinished sentences}} ==Radiation== Matter that release Radiant Heat Energy into the ==Radiation Types==
===Electric Radiation=== Matter coeructs electricity and release Radiant Heat Energy into # Change in Tempen ure # Release Radiant Heat Energy as Photon
:[[File:Blackbody-lg.png|500px]]
:{| class="prettytable" width=100% ! Characteristics !! Symbol !! f < fo !! f = fo !! f > fo |- | Speed|| <math>v</math> || <math>\lambda f</math> || C || C |- | Wavelength || <math>\lambda </math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{v}{f}</math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{C}{fo}</math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{C}{nfo}</math> |- | Energy || <math>E</math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{v}{f}</math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{C}{fo}</math> || <math>\lambda = \frac{C}{nfo}</math> |- |}
* Mọi vật dẩn điện đều có một tần số ngưởng fo . Tần số hấp thụ nhiệt cao nhứt của mọi vật dẩn điên. * Ánh Sáng Nhiệt của Phóng Xạ Điện Tử là một [[Sóng Ánh Sáng Lưởng Tính]] . : Ánh Sáng [[Quang Tử Lượng]] :: <math>E = hnf_o = h \frac{C}{\lambda}</math> : Ánh Sáng [[Quang Tử Khối]] :: <math>E = p v</math>
===Matter Decay Radiation=== When matter Decay there is a rreuce in mass : <math>m_1 - m_2 = M</math>
Creates ̈Large of Heat :: <math>E = (m_1 - m_2) C^2 = M C^2</math>
Three streams <math>\Alpha , \Beta , \Gamma</math> :: <math>E = hf = h \frac{C}{\lambda}</math>
===Nucleus Radiation=== :<math>E_n-1 - E_n = hnf_o</math>
{{bookcat}}

==Speed of Light== Light travels at constant speed through all medium's material
<math>v = C = \lambda f </math>
When Moment travels at the speed of light
<math>p C = \frac {h C} {\lambda} </math>
When Photon waves travel at the speed of light
<math>h n f = \frac {h C} {\lambda} </math>
{{bookcat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Wootery!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:41, 29 April 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with "{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|Next..."
revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu|Edit Menu]]}}
The File drop down box is the first item located on the Control Bar. It allows you to save, run, and compile your map, as well as perform a number of useful configuration programs.
==New(Control+N)== Creates a new blank map.
==Open...(Control+O)== Open a previously created or downloaded map. A set of recently opened maps will appear at the bottom of the File drop down box, for easy access to a map you've previously been working on.
==Close== Closes a currently opened map. Of course you can always skip this step and simply move onto opening another map, thereby closing the current map automatically.
==Save(Ctrl+S)== Saves the current version of an already created map.
==Save as== Saves a newly created map as a brand new file.
==Export==
==Export Again==
==Export to .DXF==
==Run Map(F9)== Compiles and launches your map, allowing you to personally play test it in game. You do not have to save the changes to your map in order for them to appear in game. On occasion, if you accidentally press F10 instead of F9, you're temporarily unable to launch your map by hotkey, so simply use the button located in the File drop down box.
==Convert WAD to VMT...==
==Reload Sounds==
==Exit== Closes out the Hammer Editor. Does not close out the Application Browser. Of course this can alternatively be done by clicking the red 'X' icon in the top right corner.
=Notes= * If you are currently editing a map when you select the new, open, close, save, save as, or exit button, a question box will appear asking if you'd like to save any currently unsaved changes to your map.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu|Edit Menu]]}}

page.title: Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu

revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=Edit Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/File Menu|File Menu]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Map Menu|Map Menu]]}}
The Edit Menu on the Control Bar houses a variety of useful tools that can assist you in creating your map.
==Undo(CTRL+Z)== This button undos any action or edit you've made to anything in your level. The undo button has a limit.
==Redo(CTRL+Y)== This button gives you the opportunity to redo an undo. The Redo button has a limit.
==Toggle Undo/Redo== This button toggles ON and OFF your ability to use the Redo and Undo tools.
==Find Entities(Ctrl+Shift+F)== This button opens a small search box that allows you to search any entity you have in your level, in case you have misplaced them. (add image of find entity search box)
==Replace...(Ctrl+Shift+R)== This button opens a small search box that allows you to take any entity in your map and replace it with another. (add image of replace search box)
==Cut(Ctrl+X)== Cuts a selected brush or entity out of the level and onto your clip board, for it to be pasted.
==Copy(Ctrl+C)== Copies a selected brush or entity out of the level and onto your clip board, for it to be pasted.
==Paste(Ctrl+V)== Pastes whatever item you have in your clipboard onto the map. Because the button pastes the item as soon as you click it, making it difficult to aim where you paste it when using the drop down box, so it's smarter to use the hotkey.
==Paste Special==
==Delete(Del)== Deletes any selected brush or entity within the map.
==Clear Selection== De-selects any brush or entity you have selected in the map.
==Select All== Simultaneously selects all brushes and entities in the entire map.
==Properties== Shows the current properties of a selected entity.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=Edit Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/File Menu|File Menu]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Map Menu|Map Menu]]}}

{{cuisine|Texas}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North America]] | [[Cookbook:United States|United States]] '''Texas cuisine''' is a cuisine, the fundamentals of which are deeply rooted in the history of [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] production in [[wikipedia:Texas|Texas]] and the difficult life of a particular group early Texas settlers, primarily those settlers who started immigrating into what was then the Mexican state of [[wikipedia:Coahuila y Tejas|Coahuila y Tejas]] from the U.S. in the early 1800’s. Several fundamental recipes of modern Texas cuisine are based on the cuisine developed by these particular early settlers (who were aided by substantial contributions from other cuisines of the time).
Texas cuisine also includes contributions from the cuisines of later immigrants to Texas which augmented the early Texas cuisine, and can also be considered to include a very wide variety of recipes and food items thought to have originated in Texas, or which are otherwise attributed to Texas, which are not based on, or related to, the early historic roots of Texas cuisine.
Perhaps some of the very most fundamental recipes of Texas Cuisine to learn and attempt to master are [[Cookbook:Southern Cornbread|cornbread]], [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans Recipe from Central Texas|pinto beans]], [[Cookbook:Original Texas-Style Chili|chili]], and, for a group, barbecued or smoked beef brisket.
Texas cuisine is distinguishable from [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]] in that the foundations of Texas cuisine seem to relate more to the cuisine developed by the particular group of settlers mentioned above, although there are overlaps, similarities, and substantial borrowing between the two.

revision.comment: comment about examples within the command listing
revision.text: I had mixed feeling about the use of examples in the GHCi command list, i.e. the use of specific module names. I think by this point, the concept should be clear without the concrete examples. The challenge is how to express clearly when something is an example. I don't have strong feelings here though. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 04:17, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

{{archive nav}} In the first listing, 
where less = filter (< x) xs
and below - don't work in my GHCi. Have to write it like this: 
	where
	less = filter (< x) xs
etc. :Are you sure? I copied-and-pasted it into h.hs, and did a :load "/home/gwern/h.hs" within GHCi and sure enough: *Main> quickSort [1,5,8,15,1,3,4] [1,1,3,4,5,8,15] :----[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 20:08, 8 February 2007 (UTC) I was wrong: the trouble was caused by an editor with non-monospace font, so while it seemed that code is well indented, it was, in fact, not. Sorry. == almost completed? == calling Eric: now that this section has the currying section filled up, can you just give it a revision and remove that irriatating 50% completed symbol? — 58.106.132.214, 2008-02-26T10:14:26 I'll at least remove the stub tag. —[[User:Toby Bartels|Toby Bartels]] ([[User talk:Toby Bartels|talk]]) 21:56, 18 November 2008 (UTC) == 2014-04-29 refactoring == The case for quickSort [x] = [x] is strictly unnecessary. Do we want to omit it? Is it good form to include it in real programs? If so, I say we keep it and explain why it helps. I'm guessing it is more efficient. Despite Haskell's laziness, maybe this is faster than running through the full recursive pattern to verify that a single-element list stays the same. If so, we should explain. If not, maybe we should just remove this extraneous thing. Or maybe it should just be a comment but not be included in the actual example code. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 16:52, 29 April 2014 (UTC) :I think we should remove it. While it might help performance a little bit, the cute one-liner quicksort we use here is relatively inefficient anyway (three passes through filter per step, indiscriminate usage of (++)), so there is no need to bother with small optimisations like that one. As for the "this is more explicit" justification in the book, it is far off the mark - adding redundant patterns makes code harder to read. Even in things like Data.List, which was written to provide decent performance, you don't find [x] patterns (the only one in Data.List is a genuine base case in the mergesort implementation).--[[User:Duplode|Duplode]] ([[User talk:Duplode|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Duplode|contribs]]) 09:09, 30 April 2014 (UTC) :I removed those. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 18:36, 30 April 2014 (UTC) Something with the indentation is wrong in the code now, but I'm not sure what the issue is, why it is wrong. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 18:16, 29 April 2014 (UTC) :Do you have any specific code block in mind? After a quick glance I didn't see anything strange (other than the where clauses indented half a mile to the right for no good reason).--[[User:Duplode|Duplode]] ([[User talk:Duplode|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Duplode|contribs]]) 09:09, 30 April 2014 (UTC) : I adjusted the extreme indentation, but it was the second and third cases under the where were not lining up quite right in my rendering. To fix it, I moved all three cases to separate lines from the where.

{{archive nav}}
== List comprehensions == I'm reading the book from the beginning, and the List comprehensions part seems way too complicated: particularly because of "(we'll assume that a test for evenness exists called ifEven):" is a bad assumption ;-). If I can't try out the code, I can't experiment with it, and I can't understand it. --gerymate
:That any better now? --[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 18:40, 27 October 2006 (UTC)
::Better for me, but I think, list comprehensions are way too high level for this stage. At this point we haven't learnt control structures, neither | this | that statements, nor the term "otherwise". "mod" is also new here, but it's all right... I think, list comprehensions shouldn't be in the 'Haskell Basics' section. --gerymate
:::Oh. I didn't even realize that guards hadn't been covered yet. As for mod... it might be rewritable in terms of regular old division (since that's what mod really is). As for 'otherwise', isn't that pretty clear? --[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 02:09, 28 October 2006 (UTC)
== Missing Material == Shouldn't the discussion of lists include a mention of the "head" and "tail" functions? I was completely lost trying to do what I thought was simple list processing (with my only exposure to Haskell so far being this tutorial), until another reference (http://www.cs.utah.edu/~hal/docs/daume02yaht.pdf) mentioned those two functions. I knew there had to be some car/cdr equivalent, and just as car/cdr are among the first Lisp functions you would learn, shouldn't head/tail be mentioned here?
== Pattern matching should have been explained a while ago ==
Please see the [[Haskell/Notes_for_contributors|notes for contributors]]. --[[User:Digichoron|Digichoron]] ([[User talk:Digichoron|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Digichoron|contribs]]) 17:27, 5 April 2011 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Imjagpul!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 09:53, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

{{TopNav|prev=Managing Rights|next=}} {{BookCat}}
__TOC__
Since its first days SQL includes a basic form of '''pattern matching on strings'''. The feature is part of the WHERE clause and is triggered by the key word LIKE. It knows two meta-characters: '_' (underscore) and '%' (percent). SELECT * FROM WHERE LIKE ; -- The like_criterion can contain '_' and/or '%' Over time, additional functionality has been incorporated to the standard. This concerns regular expressions, which are similar to those defined by [[Regular_Expressions/POSIX_Basic_Regular_Expressions|POSIX]], and regular expressions as defined by [http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions/#string.match XQuery 1.0 / XPath 2.0 function fn:matches()]. Finally the SQL application package [[w:SQL#Standardization|ISO/IEC 13249-2:2003 Part 2: Full-Text]] defines methods and functions for information retrieval on fulltext. == LIKE == The LIKE predicate compares a column of type CHAR or VARCHAR (string) with a pattern. This pattern is also a string, but it may contain two characters with a special meaning. The '_' (underscore) represents exactly one arbitrary character and '%' (percent) represents a string of zero, one or more characters. All other characters represent themselfes. The first example retrieves all rows from table ''person'' with a first name starting with the two characters 'Jo', eg: 'John', 'Johanna' or 'Jonny W.'. As the meta-character '%' represents also zero characters, rows with the first name 'Jo' are also retrieved. SELECT * FROM person WHERE firstname LIKE 'Jo%'; The next example retrieves all rows from table ''person'' with a last name similar to 'Meier', eg: 'Meyer' or 'Maier'. The two underscores represents exactly two (arbitrary) characters. Consider, that there may be unexpected results like 'Miler' (but not 'Miller'). SELECT * FROM person WHERE lastname LIKE 'M__er'; The definition of the two meta-characters '_' and '%' implies a problem: What if one wants to search for this characters itself? The solution is the same as in other programming languages: one defines an escape mechanism to mask the meta-characters and prefix the meta-character in the pattern by this escape character. In SQL the syntax is: ... WHERE LIKE ESCAPE ;
-- Retriev one of the meta-characters: 'Electric_Motor' but not 'Electric Motor' SELECT * FROM parts WHERE partname LIKE 'Electric\_Motor' ESCAPE '\';
-- Retrieve the escape character itself: 'Electric\Motor' but not 'Electric Motor' SELECT * FROM parts WHERE partname LIKE 'Electric\\Motor' ESCAPE '\'; The escape character can be any character, it is not limited to the back slash, eg.: ... ESCAPE '!' == POSIX Semantic == In an outdated version of the SQL standard there was the key word SIMILAR which introduced a pattern match in the sence of [[Regular_Expressions/POSIX_Basic_Regular_Expressions|POSIX]]. Nowadays it is deprecated. Some implementations offer pattern matching, but use arbitrary key words like REGEXP, REGEXP_MATCHES, REGEXP_LIKE or operators like '~' to activate the feature. == XQuery Semantic == The SQL standard defines the key word LIKE_REGEX to activate pattern matching as defined by [http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions/#string.match XQuery 1.0 / XPath 2.0 function fn:matches()]. == Full-Text == The SQL standard is complemented by ''ISO/IEC 13249 SQL Multimedia and Application Packages''. Part 2 ''Full-Text'' defines routines and methods for information retrieval in text documents. It deals with objects like: word, phrase, sentence and paragraph. Therein are special constructs to seach for words or phrases, words within a definable distance, thesaurus features like broader terms of a word, soundex-similarity, ranking of results, and much more. The central methode of this features is CONTAINS. -- Retrieve rows with 'word_1' and 'word_2' (in this order) within a sequence of 10 words. SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE CONTAINS(' "word_1" NEAR "word_2" WITHIN 10 WORDS IN ORDER ') = 1; Such features are fare beyond pattern matching - but it is the natural next step. SQL implementations offer them mostly in combination with special text indexes.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Lemorrison!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:55, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

Introduction:
==Background==
==Explosion==
==Aftermath==
==Factors Leading to Explosion== Multiple factors worked in tangent to lead to the eventual failures that resulted in the refinery explosion. Such factors included technical failures, human errors, as well as organizational and regulatory failing. In the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board reports, organizational failings such as corporate cost-cutting and failure to invest in safety infrastructure as well as the lack of safety culture were listed as the major contributing factor to the explosion.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report">{{Citation | journal= U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board | title= Investigation Report - Refinery Fire and Explosion and Fire | month= March | day= 23 | year = 2005 | city= BP Texas City | url=http://www.propublica.org/documents/item/csb-final-investigation-report-on-the-bp-texas-city-refinery-explosion | accessdate= May 1, 2014}}</ref> These underlying issues manifested in the technical failures such as the undersized blow down drum which started the cascade leading to the eventual catastrophe. <ref name="BP Report">{{Citation | title= BP Fatal Accident Investigation Report -Isomerization Unit Explosion Final Report | city = Texas City | state = Texas | country= USA | month= December | day = 9 | year = 2005 | chapter= Executive Summary}}</ref>
===Managerial Transitions=== Since BP’s acquisition of Amoco who owned the plant before 1998, there have been five plant manager transitions in the six year leading up to the explosion (1999-2005).<ref name="NYT Boldness">{{Citation | last1=Lyall | first1= Sarah |display-authors=1 | title = In BP’s Record, a History of Boldness and Costly Blunders | journal = New York Times | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/13/business/energy-environment/13bprisk.html |month= July | day = 13 | year = 2010 | accessdate= May 1, 2014}}</ref> This rapid change in management at the plant contributed to a lack of leadership accountability as managers are not held accountable to mishaps after their departure. The lack of leadership accountability in turn led to the lack of safety investments due to managers’ short event horizon and desire to demonstrate ability to comply with lean operation and corporate directives.
===Human Factors=== Human errors also played a major role in the Texas City Refinery explosion. Due to lack of funding and focus on safety, employees were often undertrained and lacked adequate supervision for process startup or change over. Plant employees at the time had been working 12-hour days for 30 days in a row, often with 2 hour commutes.<ref name="Financial Times">{{Citation | last1= McNulty | first1= Sheila | display-authors=1 | title = Blowdown: how faults at BP led to one of America's worst industrial disasters | journal= Financial Times | url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/510bf8fc-8f05-11db-a7b2-0000779e2340.html?siteedition=intl#axzz30PDOWNIc | month = December | day = 19 | year = 2006 | accessdate = May 1, 2014}}</ref> These employee weaknesses combined and factored into the lack of immediate response to stop the progression of events leading up to the explosion.
===Aging Plant=== [[Image:CSB 080114 BP death Wideview.jpg|right|thumb|Worn condition of ultracracker unit]] Technical issues also contributed to the demise of the refinery. The plant was constructed in 1937 and was 70 years old and dilapidated at time of explosion. In the 30 years prior to the explosion, which dates before BP acquisition of Amoco, there were already 23 fatalities. A report by an independent auditing agency, the Telos group, cited broken alarms and gauges and outdated and undersized equipment.<ref name="Financial Times" /> After the explosion, the final report by U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board cited a plethora of technical failings such as inadequate pressure relief valves and undersized raffinate towers.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report" /> Geoffrey Gioja, a co-author of the Telo’s group audit stated 'We have never seen a site where the notion 'I could die today' was so real." A particularly revealing fact of the state of the plant is that workers for a time passed a billboard commemorating two colleagues scalded to death by boiling water in 2004.<ref name="Financial Times" />
===Organizational Failure=== [[Image:BP Logo.svg|right|thumb|80px|BP lacked a culture of safety and accountability]] BP's lack of culture for safety and accountability represented an organizational failure that penetrated through BP's corporate levels. This was particularly evident in the fact that instead of investing in much needed safety renovations, in 1999, senior executives made a 25% cut in fixed costs for the Texas City Refinery.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report"/> This fixed cost cut exerted financial pressure on managers making allocation of resource toward much needed safety improvements even more unlikely. BP’s organizational and culture failure also includes the inability to accept fault and constructive criticism. Even after the disaster, BP denied fault for cutting Texas City Refinery costs with the suggestion that the cut was not a "directive" but a "challenge" to achieve safety target without compromising profitability.<ref name="NYT Boldness" /> The mentality of the BP executives at the time may best be exemplified by BP exec John Manzoni, who was asked to visit the refinery while on vacation. John Manzoni later commented "we spent the day there -at the cost of a precious day of my leave."<ref name="Financial Times" />
===Lack of Economic Incentives=== [[Image:US-OSHA-Logo.svg|right|thumb|OSHA regulates plant safety]] The plant explosion and BP's lack of safety culture may both be partially explained by the lack of economic incentives for safety. Prior to the explosion, Occupation Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) found what they called 300 "egregious, willful violations", for which OSHA only enforced a maximum fine of $21m.<ref name="Financial Times" /> Considering that BP's yearly revenue was $254b around 2005, the 21 million dollar fine was not a justifiable punishment and was not effective in eliciting improvements on plant safety and safety culture from BP.<ref name="BP Revenue">{{Citation | title=BP Revenue in 2005 | journal=wikinvest : Data Source by NASDAQ, BATS Exchange, SEC and Xignite Inc.| accessdate = May 1, 2014 | url = http://www.wikinvest.com/stock/BP_%28BP%29/Data/Revenue/2005}}</ref> This fine was incidentally also significantly lower than the projected $1bn required for safety improvements, which meant that it was much more economical for BP to take the fine rather ran implementing safety measures.
==Other Catastrophes== ==Conclusions and Generalizations==
{{BookCat}}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text: [[File:Great Auk (Pinguinis impennis) specimen, Kelvingrove, Glasgow - geograph.org.uk - 1108249.jpg|thumbnail|right]] The '''[[w:Great Auk|Great Auk]]''' (''Pinguinus impennis'') was a flightless bird of the [[w:alcid|Auk]] family that became extinct in the mid-19th century. It was the only modern species in the genus [[w:Pinguinus|Pinguinus]], a group of birds that formerly included one other species of flightless giant auk from the Atlantic Ocean region. It bred on rocky, isolated islands with easy access to the ocean and a plentiful food supply, a rarity in nature that provided only a few breeding sites for the auks. When not breeding, the auks spent their time foraging in the waters of the [[w:North Atlantic|North Atlantic]], ranging as far south as northern [[w:Spain|Spain]] and also around the coast of [[w:Canada|Canada]], [[w:Greenland|Greenland]], [[w:Iceland|Iceland]], the [[w:Faroe Islands|Faroe Islands]], [[w:Norway|Norway]], [[w:Ireland|Ireland]], and [[w:Great Britain|Great Britain]]<sup>[[w:Great Auk|1]]</sup>.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Colin Pye!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 09:00, 1 May 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: Discussion of a removed exercise (moved from [Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation https://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation&oldid=934887]).
revision.text:
== Discussion from Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation == I'm confused about one thing: Would the solution to the second exercise be 
  of {a
     ;b
      c
     ;d
  }where
  {a
  ;b
  ;c
  ;do
 {you
  like
 ;the
}}way
 i let {myself
        abuse
       ;these
 }layout rules
or 
  of {a
     ;b
      c
     ;d
  }where
  {a
  ;b
  ;c
  }do
 {you
  like
 ;the
}way
 i let {myself
        abuse
       ;these
 }layout rules
? According to the 3 rules given in the indentation chapter, since do is at the same level as the preceding expression, c, a semicolon should be added instead of a close brace. HOWEVER: 
main = do
  print x
  where
    x = 5
prints 5 (in GHC), whereas 
main = do
  {print x
  ;where
    {x = 5}}
gives "parse error on input `where'" even though where is on the same level of indentation as print x so according to the 3 rules, a semicolon should be inserted. However 
main = do
  {print x
  }where
    {x = 5}}
successfully parses and prints 5. -[[User:Qeny|Qeny]] 11:27, 31 July 2007 (UTC) :Uh-oh. You might have found a bug in my interpretation of the Haskell report. Would you be willing to chase up on it? The informal explanation in [http://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/lexemes.html#sect2.7 Section 2.7] and [http://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/syntax-iso.html#layout Section 9.3] has the more precise rules. If not, please check with the Haskell Café or the #haskell channel. Sorry! -- [[User:Kowey|Kowey]] 12:04, 31 July 2007 (UTC) ::To follow up: I suspect that the relevant snippet is "A close brace is also inserted whenever the syntactic category containing the layout list ends; that is, if an illegal lexeme is encountered at a point where a close brace would be legal, a close brace is inserted.", so maybe there needs to be a fourth informal rule, like "if you see something unexpected, (like 'where'), insert a close brace", but maybe that would have its own share of bugs. (FWIW, the first solution looks more like what I was expecting; on the other hand, for your minimal example, this new fourth rule would explain the second ws to layout translation). Frankly, I don't really know much what I'm talking about and was only interpreting the Haskell Report to the best of my ability. -- [[User:Kowey|Kowey]] 12:09, 31 July 2007 (UTC) :::I think that's exactly what we should be put for the fourth rule, then everything would be okay. I guess the question for the example though, is whether "do" is an illegal lexeme to be in a where list. I would guess that it is, because afaik a where list item always supposed to be like indentifier = expression. And what is a lexeme anyway, are a, b, and c lexemes? I guess they would be legal but invalid 'cause they aren't followed by = something. --[[User:Qeny|Qeny]] 08:28, 1 August 2007 (UTC)

[[File:Stop x nuvola with clock.svg|40px|left|link=]] '''[[Wikibooks:Blocking policy|You cannot edit]] for 2 days due to disruptive editing'''. You are welcome to contribute constructively when editing privileges are restored. You may appeal this action with a reasonable argument by adding the text {{tlx|unblock|Your reason here}} below.
--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 11:58, 1 May 2014 (UTC)

{{Grammarnavigation}}
== ਸੰਬੰਧਕ (Postposition) == Postpositions in Punjabi link nouns, pronouns and phrases to other parts of the sentence in the same way prepositions do in English, the only difference being that postpositions follow the noun whereas the prepositions precede it. Some Punjabi postpositions are ਨੇ, ਨੂੰ, ਉੱਤੇ, ਦਾ, ਕੋਲੋਂ, ਨੇਡ਼ੇ, ਲਾਗੇ etc.
== Inflection of postpositions == Some postpositions inflect(change form) to conform in number, gender or case to the following noun or phrase. For example compare ਮੋਹਨ ਦਾ ਪੈੱਨ with ਮੋਹਨ ਦੀ ਕਿਤਾਬ. Postposition ਦਾ in the first phrase agrees with ਪੈੱਨ in number and gender, both being singular and masculine. In the second phrase ਦੀ agrees with ਕਿਤਾਬ in number and gender, both being singular and feminine. Now take another example ਮੋਹਨ ਦੀਆਂ ਕਿਤਾਬਾਂ. Here again ਦੀਆਂ agrees with ਕਿਤਾਬਾਂ in number and gender, both being plural and feminine. The rules for change of form of such postpositions are generally the same as applicable to adjectives.
At times a postpositional phrase is used instead of a single postposition. For example phrase ਮੇਜ ਦੇ ਉਪਰ ਕਿਤਾਬ contains postposition ਦੇ ਉਪਰ. In such cases the second part of the composite postposition inflects like a noun, that is there is no concord with the following noun or phrase but but the concord is with the following verb. See for example ਮੇਜ਼ ਦੇ ਉੱਪਰੋਂ ਕਿਤਾਬ ਚੁੱਕੀ.
== Uninflected postpositions == Many postpositions do not inflect at all. The postpositions, ਨੇ, ਨੂੰ and ਤੋਂ always immediately follow the noun. When ਨੇ and ਨੂੰ succeed certain pronouns they are converted into suffixes like ਮੈਨੂੰ, ਤੈਨੂੰ, ਉਹਨੂੰ, ਉਹਨੇ, ਇਹਨੇ etc. When ਤੋਂ follows some pronouns it becomes ਥੋਂ and results in ablative case form of those pronouns, e.g. ਮੈਥੋਂ, ਤੈਥੋਂ etc.
[[Category:Punjabi|Grammar]]

{{BookCat}} Kenneth Kendrick is known as the whistleblower in the 2009 salmonella outbreak from contaminated peanuts. Kendrick disclosed information about factory conditions at the Peanut Corporation of America that prompted the FDA to recall over 3,600 peanut products. ==Background== [[File:Kenneth Kendrick.jpg|right|thumb|Kenneth Kendrick]]

Earlier, we discussed how [[../Permutation cipher/]] and [[../Transposition ciphers/]] work for people who know the secret key. Next, we'll discuss how, in some cases, it is possible for a person who only has the ciphertext -- who doesn't know the secret key -- to recover the plaintext.
The frequency distribution of the letters in any transposition or permutation ciphertext is the same as the frequency distribution for plaintext.
== breaking columnar transposition ciphers ==
The frequency distribution of digrams can be used to help break columnar transposition ciphers. <ref> Prof. H. Williams. [http://www.krapp.org/hydra/courses/analysis/2c-Trans.pdf "Transposition Ciphers"]. section "Analysis of columnar transposition ciphers". Retrieved 2014-05-01. </ref>
== breaking double columnar transposition ciphers ==
== breaking turning grille ciphers ==
Turning grilles, also called Fleissner grilles, ...
A guess at some sequence of two or more consecutive holes of the grill in one position of the grill (by a "known word" or an expected common digraph) can be "checked" by seeing if those holes, after the grill is rotated a half-turn, produce reasonable digraph.<ref> Helen Fouché Gaines. [http://books.google.com/books?id=CRLPYrG_LAAC "Cryptanalysis: A Study of Ciphers and Their Solution"]. 1956. section "The Turning Grille". p. 29 to 36. </ref><ref> [http://www.nku.edu/~christensen/Elementary%20Crs%20in%20Cryptanalysis%209%20-%2012.pdf "Elementary Course in Cryptanalysis: Assignment 9: Grille Transposition Ciphers"]. </ref>
== breaking other grille ciphers ==
== Further reading == <references/>

{{Grammarnavigation}}
== ਵਿਸ਼ੇਸ਼ਣ (Adjective) == An adjective is a modifier which modifies or qualifies a noun or pronoun. There can be #Qualitative(ਗੁਣ-ਵਾਚਕ) adjectives, #*For example ਚੰਗਾ, ਠੰਡੀ and ਕਾਲ਼ੇ in ਚੰਗਾ ਲੜਕਾ, ਠੰਡੀ ਹਵਾ and ਕਾਲ਼ੇ ਬੱਦਲ are qualitative adjectives. #Numerical(ਸੰਖਿਆ-ਵਾਚਕ) adjectives, #*ਇੱਕ, ਕੁੱਝ and ਬਹੁਤ in ਇੱਕ ਮੁੰਡਾ, ਕੁੱਝ ਕੁੜੀਆਂ and ਬਹੁਤ ਸ਼ੇਰ are all numerical adjectives. #Quantitative(ਪਰਿਮਾਣ-ਵਾਚਕ) adjectives, #*ਥੋੜ੍ਹਾ, ਬਹੁਤਾ and ਕਾਫੀ in ਥੋੜ੍ਹਾ ਦੁੱਧ, ਬਹੁਤਾ ਪਾਣੀ and ਕਾਫੀ ਖਾਣਾ are all quantitative adjectives. #Demonstrative(ਨਿਸ਼ਚੇ-ਵਾਚਕ) adjectives, #*Similarly ਉਹ, ਇਹ and ਹਾਹ in ਉਹ ਮੁੰਡਾ, ਇਹ ਸ਼ਹਿਰ and ਹਾਹ ਕਿਤਾਬ are demonstrative adjectives. #Pronominal(ਪੜਨਾਵੀਂ) adjectives. #*Finally ਕਿਹੜਾ, ਜਿਸ and ਉਸ in ਕਿਹੜਾ ਵਿਦਿਆਰਥੀ, ਜਿਸ ਮਾਂ and ਉਸ ਰੱਬ are all pronominal adjectives.
=== Inflection of Adjectives === Some adjectives change form to conform to number and case of the modified noun or pronoun. These adjectives bear gender and change form for number and case. For example, ਸੋਹਣਾ, ਕਾਲਾ and ਗੋਰਾ are all inflected adjectives for masculine gender and ਸੋਹਣੀ, ਕਾਲੀ and ਗੋਰੀ are the corresponding forms for feminine gender.
Inflected adjectives change like nouns taking different cases. Different forms of ਸੋਹਣਾ are ਸੋਹਣਾ, ਸੋਹਣੇ and ਸੋਹਣਿਆਂ. Inflectional form of feminine form ਸੋਹਣੀ are ਸੋਹਣੀ and ਸੋਹਣੀਆਂ.
=== Uninflected adjectives === This class of adjectives do not change form for gender, number or case e.g. ਲਾਲ, ਮਿਹਨਤੀ, ਮਸ਼ਹੂਰ, ਦਿਲਚਸਪ etc.
{{Punjabi/Navigation bottom|Verb|Adverb}} [[Category:Punjabi|Grammar]]
